reviews.comment: Steve is a fantastic prof - his lectures are fun, engaging, and he explains concepts super clearly. The course can be challenging, but he's always available to help. Definitely use unstuck ai alongside the free textbook for extra practice!
One of my favorite prof, his CPSC 312 lectures are amazing, the workload might not be low but the grading is very flexible. Also great vibe. Enjoy the soundness.
Definitely recommend steve for cpsc 210. Explains everything well and the lectures are also fun to go to.
Best professor I've ever met.

Too many micro assignments that are distracting from actual learning. A normal class would have hw, midterm, and a final. This class has pre class stuff, in class stuff, labs, quizzes, and a final. Good prof though.

This guy teaches the course in the most annoying, hassle-inducing way imaginable: there are 20 different exercises which are mandatory to complete; each is mostly trivial but, in aggregate, require you to devote a significant portion of your attention to remembering when each little pointless assignment is due.

Steve is great, he explains the concepts in a clear and understandable manner.If you go to his OH, you will learn the material in depth.The exams however will be tough and the course is graded very tough due to it all being online. So very little partial marks available.

LOVE Steve! He works hard to ensure every student succeeds and will spend time working through questions with you if you attend office hours. His pacing during lectures was excellent and he made material that was (to me) rather boring into very interesting subject matter. Would definitely take his class again!

Steve is AMAZING. His sense of humour translates throughout the lecture and slides, and he explains things in a clear fashion. It's very easy to approach him during lectures or office hours, and you might even get to listen to a nice tune on the ukulele about Java :D Course does pick up pace quickly, so be sure to stay on-track.
One of the best prof I've ever met. His lecture is super interesting and fun!
An excellent prof. His lectures are clear, direct, purposeful, and so so funny. My favourite class, my favourite prof.

I barely went to lectures. The few times I went though, I enjoyed Steve's humour and lightheartedness. I mean, one time, he brought a ukulele into class and got us all to sing a little song about Java that he had written. I also appreciate the help during the lecture lab portion of lectures (20-30 minutes of working by yourself with help available)

Steve is an exceptional professor and a wonderful human being. His instruction is easy to follow along because he understands how to explain concepts in ways that reduce cognitive load on the audience. He welcomes in-lecture questions (even "dumb" ones) with a warm patience, and does a great job at keeping you engaged in the lecture!
Very passionate, answers questions outside of class well.

Steve is AMAZING. I wish all of my classes are with him tbh bc he's literally so kind guys, like I'm stupid but he still willingly helps me and treats me like any other student even though I'm literally behind everyone else. Meanwhile in 110 Kemi made me feel like trash when I failed my mt and asked her for help :(

Steve is just so wholesome and funny. Really knows his stuff. Really eager to answer questions during lecture and on Piazza. He brings a lot of enthusiasm to class and makes you excited to learn. He also sang songs for us :) One thing about the course is that during class he repeats whatever we learned in edX so sometimes it can be a bit dreary.
Steve Wolfman is an amazing professor. He makes rather difficult topics seem easy. In addition to how well he teaches, he is also really funny and a genuine guy.
Pretty sure this guy is a genius (more than just "professor" smart)! Awesome teacher to boot, explains things so well and has the patience of a saint.

Dr. Wolfman is super passionate and engaging! He's not only all over the lecture hall eagerly helping students out, but also all over Piazza answering questions in detail. Any ambiguities or mistakes on exams he makes sure to go out of his way to address. Dr. Wolfman is also very knowledgeable and clear and concise w/ his explanations. Great prof!!

Wolfman was an amazing prof. I have taken CPSC 110 and 121, and 100% my favourite CS professor so far. His lectures are clear and organized, and the time is split up well. He is so willing to help outside of class hours/in office hours/piazza. He is the kindest man, and truly cares about his students' well being. I could not recommend him more!
Steve was wonderful all semester. Every time I entered his office during hours I would enter extremely confused but I would leave finally understanding how it all works.

Steve is INCREDIBLE!! The course is certainly not easy, but he makes it all look so simple. I actually used to look forward to his lectures. The HWs and PAs are tough, but if you start early and attend office hours, you'll get through it. He actually stayed back for an extra 30mins after his office hours ended to help me debug.

Steve is a machine. He reads every single Piazza post and often posts helpful and lengthy replies. I don't know how he does it. Ultimately his lectures are too chaotic, frantic, and scattered for my tastes and I would opt for another lecturer. But his explanations and desire to help outside of lecture are spectacular.

Steve is hands down my best prof this term, truly cares about the content and responds to almost every comment on piazza in a class of over (400? or more?) students. He is very clear at explaining and truly embodies the "there are no stupid questions" philosophy as we all learned something for the first time once. 100/10, would take again

66% of grade was over 7 tests, chance to make up 2, and drop the lowest, but the catch is the tests were too hard. It was an exercise in learned helplessness. Content was too theoretical and we spent time memorizing and handling trick questions with respect to what seemed like useless interpretation/naming of pieces of a language. Good lectures tho

Wolfman is an amazing prof, encouraging interactive lectures. He creates a welcoming environment for questions during lectures. Also, he's very clear with what he expects us to learn and focus on for assignments and quizzes. I also appreciated that he makes lectures very accessible for those who prefer to stay virtual with recorded Zoom lectures.

He's a good teacher, I didn't realize how lucky I was to have gotten him as a prof till I took more cpsc courses and realized he was sooo much better then my other profs also I had him for cpsc 103 not 110 but the site wouldnt let me choose 103

Wolfman is truly amazing, he cares about students, teaches very succinctly, and responds outside of class on Piazza everyday. He has total control over the course and it is very organized and communicative. He also is very positive and cheerful, which improves the enjoyability of lecture. I'm not a coder and I loved intro Python.
GO TO HIS LECTURES! And just pay attention. Lots of in class examples and walks you through everything. Final had a group exam portion. You'll pass fine if you just try.
CPSC 110 is naturally a hard course especially to non-coders. Explained things quite well. No hiccups, just trust the natural recursion.

Amazing professor! Dr. Wolfman was extremely helpful, caring, and overall a great person to talk to. He made all the concepts very clear and really fostered my interest in computer science. Also quite funny at times! Would definitely recommend.

Steve is a wonderful professor. You can tell he really cares about his students and wishes for them to succeed. He is always available to help inside and outside of the classroom. He is patient and explains the material well. Although the lectures were a little long, he thoroughly covered the material and made sure everything was clear.

Steve is a great prof. He really cares about your learning and makes sure there are lots of office hours, extra help sessions and good TAs to support everyone. I learned a lot about CPSC, specifically Python and really enjoyed the course. If you do all of the work and make an effort to pay attention during lectures, this class is an easy A.

Professor Wolfman is a really nice + chill professor and makes CPSC103 an extremely approachable class for people who have no experience with CPSC. I think most of the lower reviews are from Steve's classes for senior students, so take this as a review of CPSC103 taught by him.

Steve as a professor was okay, he's a nice guy. As long as you show up to class and tutorials (which are both optional) and do all your assignments it's an easy A. The course itself was super easy and the tests were too. I had no previous experience in programming but it was a breeze.
I don't understand the negative reviews. Steve Wolfman was enthusiastic, caring, and taught quite well. I really enjoyed having him for CPSC 103.

Lectures are mostly just watching him code which is boring if you already understand the material and impossible to follow if you don't. Exam questions are worded in a way that makes it difficult to understand what is being asked of you. Seems like a genuinely nice guy who cares about his students, but just isn't the best at teaching.
He's a very nice guy, but he makes his exams and homework very hard. He grades quite tough as well.

I read that there was a lot of work in this class and I made the mistake of thinking that it was over exaggerating. It takes away from my core classes. The grading is way too hard for things we are doing for the very first time. Wolfman always says "if there's a true attempt, you will get the marks". Not true. Regret taking this class.

Steve's way of answering questions is asking you 10 more. You ask him a simple question and end up more confused than you were because he starts talking about who know what anyways don't take his class. The TA's arent that great either.
Utterly useless. Talks about wolves and his family more than the curriculum. This is not a GPA booster! TAs are horrible and so is he.

Steve is not a good prof. Plain and simple. He throws 6 assignments at your per week on top of the heavy workload you already have. People try to ask a simple question on piazza and rather than have a straight-forward answer, he asks 4 questions in return. Like no one has time for this bs. Also gloats about his tenure status when doing evaluations

Fun class. I know some people found the flipped-classroom structure and funny problem-based exams polarizing, but I loved them! Lecture-activities are super helpful for understanding concepts -- they make sure you're thinking, not just copying stuff down. Exams all about whether you learned the stuff, not whether you memorized.

Steve is an excellent prof. His lectures are interesting and his midterms are an opportunity to learn (but you MUST do the practice midterms to pass). This course could benefit from more in-class activities, and a better textbook. The material itself is difficulty, as is the grading criteria, but Steve does his best to teach it well.
One of the best profs at cs department. Be prepared before you go to lecture, otherwise, it is really hard to follow his pace.

He's really enthusiastic in his lectures, but it's really just us watching him code. So when exams roll around you're not really too sure what you're supposed to be learning about... If you want to succeed be sure to attend office hours and ask your TAs plenty of questions.

I was surprised at all these negative reviews - tbh he's one of the best profs I've ever had, and seemed genuinely very kind, entertaining, and patient. His lectures were pretty good too. I thought he was amazing, but maybe he teaches the difficult courses differently.

The problem with Steve is that he doesn't teach fundamentals (flipped classroom) and isn't clear about his learning expectations from students. Many of his problems are un-interpretable (wordy as hell) and exams constrain your thinking style to his own (horrible for any learner but reading/writing learners). Could be worse but avoid if you can.
The most enthusiastic prof I've ever had. Really articulate, and shows he cares about the subject matter and the excitement makes you appreciate the material more.

Seems to care about students a lot, but ironically one of the worst profs I've had at ubc cpsc.. Not a fan of how he expects you to understand everything from the readings before class, then blasts through writing code on the screen for the entire lecture. Won't be taking a class with him again
sacrificed clickers just to attend his class 10/10

I find steve has his own pace and it is very hard to follow his thinking process in the lecture. It is obvious that Steve enjoys teaching, but the quality of his lecture wasn't great this term. I started to study this course by using other instructor's lecture materials later this term, and I found those explanations were far better and clearer.

Steve is an amazing professor, the classes are very unusual (more thinking than listening) which is a very good way of learning. With Steve, this class is not only about programming but more generally about how to approach problems: I can only recommend you to take it. You should go to class to get the most out of it.

Very energetic and amazing! Does what has to be done real quick and leaves the rest of the times for students to solve the problems themselves. In a sense he doesn't really lecture! So if you expect a prof that does the thinking for you and tell you every answer Wolfman is not your guy! Also you have to do pre-readings for every class or you fail!
I had cpsc 320 with him. He us a smart person and thinks eveyone in his class is already a genious. His explanations are hard to follow, exam questions are hard to understand and unclear.

His lectures are probably the highlight of this course. Be prepared: the course has an ASTRONOMICAL workload (10 hours a week at least). Between the problem sets, the practice problems, the videos, labs and studying for the tests, you'll be completely screwed if you fall behind. It is not impossible; with LOTS of practice, you can do very well.

Wonderful professor, funny, interesting lectures, but an awful course. Problem sets are a pain (don't bother asking for help on them), and the videos wind up making lectures a bit redundant. Midterms and finals are rather easy as they test conceptual logic as opposed to hard core programming like the problem sets.

Weekly problem sets are a pain. They are a lot more complex than the examples and practice problems given. Usually spend +3 hours on each. But he tries to make lectures interesting, although I feel like they are redundant.
Steve is an awesome prof. Clear lectures, nice guy, whatever. CPSC 110 however, is a pretty stupid course.
Definitely  a great prof and would recommend to anyone taking 110

Steve is an amazing professor. I loved his classes. He is undoubtedly a great teacher. Of course there's the part about him being funny but also the fact that he explains everything in a lot of detail that really helped me grasp concepts faster. I'd definitely recommend his class to any of my friends!

The best prof I've ever had. Really got me interested in algorithms. Was hilarious and made the courses a lot of fun. The problems were fun to solve and the class moved at a comfortable pace. Makes the courses quite involved and interesting. I plan to take as many classes with him as possible. Also took CPSC 320 with him.

Steven is such a funny guy He always has some jokes during lectures, but sometimes he just goes too fast... No textbook but videos! I have to say that the exams are hard if you do not keep up with the material and get enough practice. It's really IMPORTANT to stay with him! Really like him
He is a excellent prof and the best prof I have seen in UBC. He taught you the method and understanding instead of just knowledge.

Before I took CPSC 110, I was planning on minoring in computer science. I don't know if it was the course or Wolfman (honestly it was probably both), but I do NOT want to minor in comp sci anymore if I have to deal with even 1% of the garbage I dealt with in CPSC 110.  If I knew how this course was beforehand,I would have never taken it
Hands down the best professor and best class I've ever taken. His exams are difficult, but pay attention and you'll learn a ton! He makes it look too easy. Practice lots of problems.

I had three classes with Steve. They were all great, he is a great lecturer. Make sure you don't skip any of his classes and you'll be fine. (his exams can be tough, but they are usually very similar to the practice exams)

Steve is funny and very approachable, and his lectures are interesting and fun.  He comes very prepared to every class, and he would would often go over time on his office hoursafter class to make sure students understood the concepts. I recommend (for 311) doing the readings ahead of time because he moves quickly over course topics. Amazing prof!

The classes were an intense 50 minutes of learning, so make sure to keep your focus. Although he generally follows the textbook, he emphasizes the most important parts making the lectures worthwhile. Entertaining as well as very educational. Very fast feedback.

Definitely cares about teaching; he puts into practice all the current theory on engaging teaching. If you actively engage yourself in his class, and actually try to enjoy the learning, you will get swept up in it. The only really really difficult part of the class is induction (unless you are an honour math student...). Definitely recommend.

He tries to be interesting in class but in the end, the quality of his teaching isn't really that great. He does go over topics and tries to make sure everyone understands by using clickers, but it's definitely hard to follow. Additionally, he tends to reward the talented and bright students much more than the average students.

I find it hard to keep up with what Steve is saying in class. He goes really fast because the material might be easy for him, but I guess it isn't like that for everybody else (or just the people I've talked to, and including myself). The midterms and finals were open book and they were killer. On the bright side though, there was scaling involved.

Steve is a funny, kind, and nice guy. He's a great prof. Textbook is completely unneeded and attendance isn't necessary—the best way to master this material is through youtube videos. If Steve really wanted to make his lectures useful, he'd get a bunch of paper cups with numbers on them for algorithm demonstrations. Too much emphasis on proofs.
Amazing prof, very enthusiastic and helpful. Got me interested in both the theoretical and hardware sides of computing.

Very excellent professor. Don't be deceived by other comments! At first, I though he was pandering to us, but then I realized he just really cares about the students and materials. Excellent professor. Very clear and knowledgable. One of my favorites.

1. If you don't know "Dr. Racket" this course will be really tough. You'll have to pretty much learn it on your own. 2. It's easy to get lost in the lectures. Talk to him immediately. He's extremely patient and won't let you leave until you get the subject. 3. Talk to the TAs they'll be able to explain it in different terms which you may need.
Tries too hard to endear himself to his students - should spend more time just teaching.  Could do with less feedback surveys and learning goals; curse you Carl Wieman!
His "innovative" teaching methods are frustrating and ineffective.  If you are looking for a clear and straightforward presentation of the material, avoid his classes.  Stop over-thinking it Wolfman.
Fantastic prof!
Not the best at delivering information. Nice guy though.
Steve is a great guy, nice and very smart but teaching is not he's thing.
You have to work in this course but he gives you more than enough to go on. He seems to really care about his students!! But why would any prof want to help slackers?!
This prof is atrocious. Fair warning to anyone considering a class with him. I'm not sure how he still has a job given his ability to teach.

One of my favourite profs (I was in his 121 class as well). 121 was definitely easier than 221 just because of the material and the expectations of the students, but this prof was great for both. Very helpful and entertaining, and obviously wants the best for his students.

I failed miserably his course at the beginning of the course but I end up passed. His exams wasn't easy, and the course required a lot of reading, understanding and determination. He's more that gladly to help you when you ask. Just don't be shy. (side note: this is 2011 sept course)
Definitely avoid if possible. Provided notes and lectures are terrible and the book is useless. Plan on spending a lot of time with the TA.

Really depends on one's style of learning. Very enthusiastic and helpful, but really have to keep up or you're left with a pile of disorganized pdf notes and a useless textbook. Recommended prof if you really pay attention during lectures and genuinely interested in the topic.
Very funny teacher, very helpful. Assignments can be a little bit challenging, but you can work in pairs. I would definitely take another his course.
Awful. Just awful. Never again

I'm fairly sure a lot of these comments are totally fake. To me, this was an awful class. I really did not like this prof. I didn't find his teaching style helpful or direct. I felt like he wanted to see everyone fail. Avoid if possible imo.
This prof will whip you hard, but after you come out of it all, you will have become a better man (and programmer).

Very good professor who is teaching a very complicated course. Got a good grade at the end, but not without a lot of hard work, and a lot of low grades inbetween as well. Very caring, and always available to help
Natural teacher. Very good explanations. Motivates students to learn. Registered in another section but went to his. Very helpful outside class. This guy was hired to teach, not research.

Writing code is his method of lecturing, so if you're used to copying notes from the whiteboard, prepare for a major shift in learning style.  Read the textbook before doing the assignments.  Midterms were "optional" and graded such that it won't penalize your final grade if you do bad.  Very helpful during office hours.

Very helpful and tries to be clear. Extremely enthusiastic and may be oblivious to the fact that you're not. Cares personally about students and tries to know everyone's name. However, he's known to some as "Darth Wolfman" for his difficult exams.

He has this uncanny ability to make every course he teaches EXTREMELY HARD!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  As a person, he's a great and interesting guy, as someone who specializes in CPSC, he's incredibly smart, but as an instructor- TOO DIFFICULT!!  I think he needs to teach Honours or Graduate-level courses instead.  Stop teaching us "normal" undergrads!!

Great instructor! As others have noticed, very hard midterms and assignments, but encourages discussion and always willing to help. Finals are more than fair to make up. You will know your sh*t well after his classes. Also he brings treats to class! Lecture notes are not stand alone, you must attend class. He just gets the harder courses to teach.
Deliberately obfuscates material and seems more intent on impressing students than teaching them.

I took CPSC 320 with Wolfman and to be honest I failed it, along with several classmates I know.  However Wolfman himself is not a terrible professor, he's extremely intelligent and engaging, and will spend time to explain things. My biggest mistake is not utilizing his OH more. He's a great guy, he's just teaching very very VEEERRYYY hard courses.

Extremely difficult class, probably the hardest in CPSC program. That being said Steve gives really hard assignments and even harder midterms (if you pass you are doing awesome!!), however if you put in the time to see him in his office hour you will get 100% on his assignments and understand the course  material alot better.

he should not teach this class, he doesnt get the fact that this is a very hard subject and makes even harder with his not clear and hard in class clicker questions. too much work last week of exams we had lab 5th assignment and final. i ill never again take any course with . unless u really need to take a course with him try to avoid him.

very enthusiastic.....interesting lectures.lots of assignments(very very hard but interesting! labs were not easy. mts were VERY HARD and LONG! final was very fair tho. not only  need to understand the material but think deeply. my favorite prof so far!

Really enthusiastic about the material and loves teaching it. Very interactive classes, with lots of discussion amongst ourselves.  In class problems and exams required good thought, so if you don't think too well don't take him.

This class was a ridiculous amount of work and I found it incredibly difficult. The midterms were challenging with a low class average, and in the last week of class we still had a lab and a huge assignment. Steve is a great person but try to get another prof if you can... I mean it.
This course was so random that I hardly remember any of the material! EVEN though I got an A-. He should really consider examining himself because if he keeps it all random, no one will benefit.

His teaching is below average. His exams are very difficult. he has office hours and will answer your questions. Best advice is if you are a newbie to the course material, avoid him if you know the course material before class, then he could be stimulating. However, you might find that he teaches many courses at UBC and there is no escape from him.
I was so worried because I got 60's on the midterm.. but in the end I got A+! I like this prof. He is very nice.

The material and exams were very challenging, but Steve was always available for answering questions, and answered questions on the discussion board daily.  Steve is enthusiastic and makes students a high priority.

Prof is alright, basically its the course that's REALLY HARD. And I guess Wolfman makes standard hard midterm for all the sections too. Assignments were a pain in the butt, frequent fridays staying in learning centre till 11pm, very picky TA markers. Labs were alright, get help from the smart ones. ALWAYS do sample midterm/quiz and understand 100%!

Lectures are not cohesive, and do not provide an incremental, step by step approach to learning the material. The lectures, and lecture notes often cannot be used as solid reference for exams. Do not expect examples to be solved in class during lecture. Exam difficulty exceeds lecture material. I will avoid taking any future classes with this prof.
-if you want a challenge

He is a very enthusiastic prof. BUT, his enthusiasm is quite useless and he confuses you by not teaching the basics and giving you extremely difficult OPEN ENDED problems in class. Not only does he pressure you with hard midterms and finals but he does not like to curve and makes the class average barely pass. midterm average..52%..... :(

Obviously knows his stuff but doesn't explain well...I come out of his lectures more confused than before I went in. He spends way too much time on trivial tidbits that are relevantly interesting BUT spends like almost zilch time on the meatiest, hardest parts of the course.

Pretty good prof, a little bit too enthusiastic sometimes (esp when it comes to his daughter...). Assignments are very easy (and relevant) but midterms/finals are REALLY hard. The course is very challenging but he made it bearable.

most engaging prof i've had so far in any class (including arts classes which tend to be more fun in lecture).  He is always enthusiastic about answering students' questions and really knows what he's talking about.  I expected this class to be really dry but with Steve lecturing, i was very wrong.

This prof spends too much time on unimportant details and too little time on important concepts.  I suspect this may be because he does not to have a good global understanding of the material.  His "enthusiasm" doesn't seem genuine (I find it irritating).

He knows his stuff and loves it too. For those interested in computer science, he is a perfect match because he neither irrelevant nor dull in the least. I chalk my general dislike of the class to my inability to connect with the subject matter. If he taught anything outside computer science, I'd sign up for that class in a heartbeat.

Give me a break, you don't get 4 science credits for nothing. This guy really know what he's talking about, and his enthusiasm shows that he really cares about what he is teaching,  one of the best prof!

i hated this class!  It sucks.  If you have no knowledge of computers, it claims to be introductory but you'll end up programming and the TA's are absolutely useless.  Steve is clearly a nice guy and i know he tries hard but it just doesn't work out that well because he goes off on a tangent and it usually makes no sense.

Steve is extremely helpful and excited about what he does. You get the feeling that he actually cares about his students' education. You do have to keep up on your readings because he doesn't spoonfeed the material to you powerpoint lecture style, he teaches you how to apply the concepts by writing code and explaining what he's doing as he goes.

I was very turned off by the way he lectures in class. He is way too over-excited about what he teaches in my opinion and thus losing focus on the course material at times, causing us to fall behind. Very responsive on webct discussion boards though. Nice prof, but very difficult to follow in lectures.

Steve seemed to have given most of the attention to a select few students in the class that had time to do bonus projects. His tests usually required you toknow more subtle parts than he bothers to teach in class and he requires you to write proofs for ill-posed statements that have counter examples. Overall very confusing prof.
He teaches very clearly, usually coding relative programs during the class. I've learn a lot of thing about concept of OOP!!

This is BEST prof ever, IMO. He is extremely engaging and always helpful. Kudos to Steve!  Textbook used was computatinal intelligence SECOND edition - the unreleased version. It's not finished yet so we were given access to the draft for free.

He may have caused us to fall behind, however, I like how he demonstrates the concepts by typing code instead of using slides. He's extremely helpful, so take full advantage of his office hours! He's also got me so much more interested in computer science that I might consider doing a minor or even a combined major.

This guy cannot differentiate between upper level courses and introductory courses.I took CPSC 121 and left the program because of him.Had I gone to Paul Carter's clas,I'd still be there.He is ADD, erratic in lecture, and plays video games instead of explaining code.I hated this guy.I study comp sci at another school and am loving it.
A great prof who explanis things very well. He is extremely interested in the material he teaches, and can impart this impart this interest to his students. He made this class a lot of fun.

Too enthusiastic for our own good- spends up to 25 minutes at the start of class on material beyond the scope of the course, causing us to fall behind. Disproportionate time allocation on important and less important topics. Goes all over the place when teaching concepts, and even in his slides. However, he is quite helpful.
Steve is one of the best instructors I've ever had!  Enthusiatic about the subject AND about teaching.  Never have I had a more prepared instructor who is so committed to teaching and learning.
He's overly excited about everything. Turned me off the course.
The guy's way too enthusiatic, but can't back up the enthusiasm with actual teaching - without the textbook he'd have gotten me failed.

Steve is one of the best professors I've ever had: he's extremely engaging, his assignments are tough but fair, and he makes even the driest material interesting.  He'll make you work hard, but you'll learn a lot.  Plus it's hard to beat a prof who buys everyone pizza after the midterm and sings for us (in costume, no less) after the final.

Try to stay away from him. He lives in his own world and tries to impose his whims on students. He discouraged students first by putting in writing that if you can't finish assignment 2, you will fail the course and then by saying that he is scheduling an early midterm so students have enough time to drop the course. Better stay away from him.

In an intro class like this lecture is most important, and steve really fails.He bounces around with no organization, talks like you've been in the industry for years,leaves you more confused than when you started.i spent this term teaching myself Java. go to Carter's 111 lecture.  trust me.steve is best for grad advising and upper level classes.

one of the best prof. CS311 is hard. it's interpreter construction. and you have to be well prepared for 411, compilor construction.  but steve is already making the course easier to understand and fun, insteresting, clear, etc. try take this course with another prof, see what you can learn and get, and u'll know steve is good.

This professor is insane. Do not take his class unless you have no social life whatsoever. I'm working on assignment 1, and it's disgusting. It took the graduate T.A. an entire day to complete when he tried it. Steve assumes the students know scheme even though there were no scheme course prerequisits. In all other cpsc courses I'm an A student.
Insanely difficult labs: between 25 and 50 hours to complete a 2 week lab.  In addition to labs, assignments took 5 - 10 hours with one assignment per week.

Steve is an awesome professor!  He is funny, helpful and clear.  Personally (unlike most people in my class) I also enjoyed his midterm and final.  They were sort of tricky, but still doable if you are fairly good at the subject. (and personally I like a challenge now and then)

I've never had a professor who cared this much about his students. You can email him at midnight and expect a reply within 10min. He works hard, and he expects you to as well. Expect to have fun, but your average may suffer. He is hard. Did I mention that already? HARD. You've been warned.

Simply, one of the best proffs I've ever had.  He probably spends 12 hours a day (or more!) preparing material for his lectures and answering students' questions.  He turned one of the most boring cs classes (cs312) to one of the most exciting classes I've ever taken in UBC  But be forwarned... Steve will make you WORK HARD... VERY VERY VERY H
He is the best prof I have ever had.  Although the class was about a few relatively obscure languages, he made it really interesting.  I learned a lot about learning languages!
Steve is a very helpful prof. He really cares about the students, and will help you FOR SURE if you ask for help. For the last day of class, he dressed up as a Panda. It was hilarious!

Probably the best prof I've ever had, really makes an effort to get everyone involved with the class and he must spend hours and hours posting helpful messages on WebCT.  Brought cookies as a consolation for our midterm.  312 is worth taking, Steve will make it interesting.
Best prof, ever.  He actually cares about what he's doing and the enthusiasm comes through clearly.
